title: Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (Clubfoot) in a 3-Month-Old Infant: Early Intervention Case Study
clinical_history: Noah is a 3-month-old male infant presenting with his mother for a routine follow-up. He was born at term via normal vaginal delivery after an uneventful pregnancy; birth weight was 3.2 kg. Immediately after birth, a persistent inward turning of his right foot was noted. Physical examination confirmed the right foot displays plantarflexion at the ankle, inversion at the subtalar joint, and adduction of the forefoot. Mild calf muscle atrophy is visible in the right leg compared to the left. Noah's mother states there are no signs of pain during handling, but he is occasionally irritable when pressure is applied to the right foot during diaper changes or stretching. He has been receiving serial casting (Ponseti method) initiated at 1 week of age, with weekly changes. His mother reports improved correction but still observes limited dorsiflexion and a tendency for the foot to revert if left unsupported for several hours.

nprs.affected_area: Posterior and medial aspect of right foot (Achilles tendon, tibialis posterior muscle, gastrocnemius/soleus, foot ligaments)

aggrevating_factors: Stretching the foot during casting or at-home exercises; pressure on the affected foot during diapering or clothing changes.
picture: [insert image of infant right foot demonstrating plantarflexion, inversion, and adduction]
easing_factors: Gentle handling; application of warm cloth post-cast removal; consoling when irritable.
past_history: No previous medical conditions or hospitalizations. No family history of clubfoot, neuromuscular disorders, or congenital anomalies.
medical_history: Full-term healthy infant. No other congenital abnormalities identified.
medications: None currently. Occasional use of topical emollient for minor skin irritation from casts.
personal_history: Lives with mother and father in a supportive household; both parents in good health, no consanguinity. Mother on maternity leave and able to attend all follow-up appointments.
imaging: Initial foot ultrasound to confirm structural deformity; no bony anomalies apart from classic talipes equinovarus alignment. No further imaging performed at this stage.
